McGregor v. Gilliland – Final Trial Preparation
Summary (Jan 20, 2026)
Court Orders and Judgments
• Final Decree of Divorce (Feb 27, 2024) – Issued after a contested trial (heard Nov 15, 2023 1 ), this
12-page decree granted joint legal custody of the two children (A.K. and B.M.) with sole physical
custody to the Father (Christopher McGregor). The Mother (Brittany Gilliland) was awarded specified
visitation (1st and 3rd Thursday–Monday weekends each month, plus alternating holidays and
summer weeks) 2 3 . The decree ordered the Father to pay the Mother ~$52,000 as half the
equity in the marital home (initial $10k + $2k/month for 21 months) 4 5 , with a clause that
failure to pay would require the house to be sold and proceeds split 6 7 . It also required the
Mother to pay $617/month in child support to the Father 8 . Key findings: The court found the
Mother had mistreated A.K. (e.g. bruising from inappropriate discipline) and that the children
thrived with the Father 9 . A DHR child-abuse investigation was opened on Nov 7, 2023 (the day
after trial) and eventually closed as “Not Indicated” (unsubstantiated) on Jan 5, 2024 10 , meaning
abuse wasn’t confirmed but concerns weren’t disproven. (Decree: Tallapoosa Cty. Case
DR-2023-900051, 11/15/23 trial before Judge Perryman)
• Post-Divorce Show-Cause Hearing & Bench Ruling (July 31, 2024) – After the final decree, Mother
and Father filed cross-petitions for contempt over visitation issues 11 . By March 2024, A.K. had
begun refusing visitation with the Mother, experiencing panic attacks at handoffs; police were
called multiple times when A.K. would not get in Mother’s car 12 . At the July 31 hearing, Judge
Steven Perryman conducted an in camera interview with 12-year-old A.K. 13 . The judge declined to
hold Father in contempt, recognizing that A.K.’s refusal was not due to father’s interference but due
to genuine strain in the mother–child relationship 14 . From the bench, Judge Perryman outlined
a graduated reunification plan: A.K. would continue individual counseling at the Child Advocacy
Center (CAC); the Mother would join some of those counseling sessions with A.K. (once the child
was receptive); the family (Mother, Father, A.K., and younger son B.M.) would have one low-pressure
meal together weekly – at flexible times (the judge “did not care if… breakfast, lunch, or
dinner” 15 ) – to normalize contact; formal reunification therapy with a specialist would occur
later, only after progress in joint counseling and family meals 14 16 . In short, the court continued
the contempt hearing generally (no immediate findings) and ordered a therapeutic intervention
period 17 . No written order was entered at that time; the bench directives were later formalized with
modifications (see below).
• Reunification Therapy Order (Written Order, Nov 6, 2024) – Over three months after the bench
ruling, a written “Final Order” was entered (drafted by Mother’s counsel) which diverged in key
ways from the oral pronouncement 18 . It ordered that reunification therapy with a specialist (Kelly
Turner, LPC) begin immediately, without any prerequisite joint sessions at CAC 19 20 . It also
mandated weekly dinners every Wednesday at 6:30pm with the whole family, making that
schedule fixed and “taking priority over all other events,” only excused for emergencies (with make-
1
up the next day) 21 22 . These terms departed from the bench ruling’s flexibility (which had allowed
any weekly mealtime and implied adjustment for the child’s schedule 15 23 ). The order also
specified that the costs of counseling be split 50/50 per the divorce decree’s rules for uninsured
medical expenses 24 . (Order: “In re: Reunification Therapy”, filed 11/6/24, Judge Perryman.)
• Contradictions: Bench vs. Written Order Discrepancies: The Father later noted the written order
“did not reflect the true wishes and order of the Court.” 25 26 Specifically, Judge Perryman had
envisioned reunification therapy only after A.K.’s individual counseling and some joint sessions with
Mother, but the written order imposed it immediately 27 25 . The judge had also intentionally left
the weekly family contact flexible (no set day or meal) 15 , whereas the order rigidly set Wednesday
dinners at 6:30pm 21 . The bench plan mentioned “lunches [and] dinners” in a casual sense and
stressed he didn’t care which mealtime as long as it happened weekly 28 29 ; the written order,
however, authorized only dinners on a fixed night, omitting the possibility of lunch and locking in a
time 30 31 . These omissions and changes became a point of contention and motion practice (see
Feb 2025 motion below).
• Order Amending Dinner Schedule (Nov 7, 2024) – The day after the reunification order, the Father’s
counsel moved to reconsider the inflexible dinner schedule. Judge Perryman issued an Amended
Order allowing that if a Wednesday dinner conflicted with a pre-scheduled activity of A.K.’s, the family
dinner could be moved to Tuesday or Thursday that week 32 33 . The judge warned against any
“gamesmanship” in claiming conflicts 34 . This modification restored some flexibility intended by the
original bench ruling. (No other substantive changes were made to the 11/6/24 order.)
• “Motion to Modify Previous Order” & Pending Final Hearing – On Feb 11, 2025 (about 3 months
after the written order), the Father – now with new counsel – filed a motion to modify or set aside the
November 6, 2024 reunification order 35 . He argued that the order should be conformed to “reflect
the wishes of the Court as expressed on July 31, 2024,” especially regarding the sequence of
therapy 36 37 . This motion (effectively a Rule 60(b) request for relief) noted the discrepancies
(therapy timing and fixed dinners) and sought to correct what Father viewed as mistakes or changed
circumstances. Judge Kevin Hall had by then taken over the case (succeeding the retiring Judge
Perryman). The record indicates this motion was not ruled on immediately and was to be
addressed in the final trial on custody/visitation set for Jan 20, 2026 38 . (In other words, the
November 2024 order remained in place pendente lite, and the issues it raised are to be resolved at
the upcoming trial.)
• Order Granting Holiday Visitation (Judge Hall, Nov 6, 2025) – With the final trial still pending into
late 2025, the Mother filed a motion to enforce holiday parenting time. On Nov 6, 2025 Judge Hall
granted the Mother’s “Motion for Court-Ordered Holiday Visitation,” explicitly noting that “there
appears to be no order suspending visitation” 39 . He therefore ordered that the Mother’s holiday
visitation rights be honored. This suggests that despite the reunification plan, the Mother’s regular
visitation from the divorce decree was never legally stopped – yet it had not been occurring, prompting her
motion. (Indeed, Father’s affidavit confirms A.K. had not had an unsupervised overnight with Mother
since August 2023 12 .) This order effectively reaffirmed the Mother’s right to holiday time in 2025,
given that no court had ever formally suspended her visitation 39 . The Father did not oppose the
holiday time on the record. Timeline note: This came after a year in which reunification efforts had
faltered (see below), and indicates the court’s intent to ensure Mother still had access pending the
final resolution.
2
• (Other Interim Orders: The file also includes minor procedural orders, e.g. an Order to Appear via
Zoom (June 6, 2025) allowing remote testimony, and appointment of a Guardian ad Litem (GAL) for
the children in late 2024 – Judge Hall granted Father’s Nov 20, 2024 motion for a GAL (the record
shows Attorney Dianne James was appointed). These ensured the children’s interests were
represented during the protracted proceedings.)
Key Evidence from Transcripts & Affidavits
• Divorce Trial Testimony (Aug–Nov 2023) – The divorce/custody trial spanned multiple days (e.g.
Aug 18 and Nov 6, 2023) before Judge Perryman. Witnesses for Father included: Father himself (C.
McGregor), who described Mother’s instability and the children’s well-being with him; Heather Dixon
(CAC counselor) who had evaluated A.K. around Sept 2023 and testified to concerns about Mother’s
anger and potential abuse, recommending supervised visitation “to start” 40 41 ; and other
family members (Lisa, Brian, Katie McGregor) corroborating the children’s thriving routine with
Father. Witnesses for Mother included: Stacy Green and Tasha Howell (friends or relatives who likely
refuted abuse claims), and the Mother herself, who denied mistreating A.K. and emphasized her
bond with the children (exhibits showed loving photos shortly before separation 42 ). Notably,
Dixon’s testimony revealed that A.K. (then 11) reported incidents of the Mother “losing self-control”
and inflicting bruises 43 . On cross, Mother’s attorney stressed that Dixon had never met the Mother
or younger child and based her opinions solely on Father’s and A.K.’s reports 44 45 . The Mother’s
side highlighted evidence (e.g. a photo from 8 days before Dixon’s intake) showing A.K. smiling with
Mother 42 to suggest A.K. wasn’t afraid at that time. In the end, Judge Perryman found sufficient
evidence of emotional and physical maltreatment by Mother (even though DHR later did not
“indicate” abuse) and that the Father provided a more stable environment, leading to the custody
award to Father 9 46 . (Transcript: Final Hearing Nov 2023, e.g. Dixon at p.89–95; Court’s findings
summarized in final decree.)
• In Camera Interview with Child (July 31, 2024) – At the contempt/show-cause hearing, Judge
Perryman interviewed A.K. privately in chambers 13 . While the transcript of this interview is sealed,
the judge stated on record that A.K. had genuine fear and resistance toward visitation with
Mother, beyond Father’s control 14 . According to Father’s affidavit, the judge emerged and
expressly acknowledged that the situation was “not appropriate at this time” to force visitation
and that the Mother-daughter relationship needed repair (hence the reunification plan) 47 14 . This
in camera insight heavily influenced the gradual approach ordered.
• Father’s Affidavit (Late 2025) – In preparation for trial, Father C. McGregor submitted a detailed
sworn affidavit (excerpted above) summarizing events since the divorce 48 . Key points from
Father’s affidavit: (1) Visitation Breakdown: A.K. has refused overnight visits with Mother since
Aug 2023, experiencing panic attacks at exchanges; police were involved multiple times in early
2024, and officers advised not to force the terrified child 12 . (2) Bench Plan vs Order: Father recounts
the July 31, 2024 bench ruling and notes the written order’s departures, but affirms “I complied
fully with the November 6 order.” 18 (He did facilitate therapy with Ms. Turner and the weekly
dinners despite misgivings). (3) Mother’s Participation Issues: From Jan–Aug 2025, roughly 30 weekly
reunification dinners were scheduled, but Mother missed well over half – often no-showing or
canceling last-minute 49 . Father provides specific dates: e.g. Jan 10, 2025 (Mother no-showed a
rescheduled Saturday brunch), Feb 5 (canceled Wed., then no-showed Thu.), Mother’s Day 2025 (she
declined a planned dinner and only picked up the son B.M.), etc., through summer 2025 when
3
Mother stated she “won’t be able to do dinners until I get back to work” and missed multiple July/
August dates 50 . Father says he attended every meeting and even moved dinners from Wed to
Sunday afternoons to accommodate Mother’s new schedule, but she still failed to attend many 51 .
(4) Mother’s Relocation and Life Changes: Mother moved ~100 miles away (Clanton, AL) in mid-2025,
got remarried and had a new baby, which, per Father, made her less available for A.K. 52 53 . (5)
Alleged Non-Compliance by Mother: Father claims Mother is $1,500 behind on child support and has
not reimbursed half of medical costs for the kids, contrary to court orders 54 . He also notes
Mother sometimes publicly accused him of “parental alienation” on social media even while he was
actively including her (e.g. she posted from his home during A.K.’s birthday, where Father had invited
Mother and her husband) 55 . Overall, the affidavit portrays Father as having over-complied and
encouraged contact, giving Mother extra holiday time and opportunities, while Mother allegedly
squandered many of those opportunities 56 57 . This sworn statement will support Father’s case
that he did not alienate A.K., but rather Mother failed to show up consistently, causing further harm
to the mother–child relationship.
• Kelly Turner (Reunification Therapist) – Conduct and Affidavit: Kelly Turner, a licensed counselor,
was appointed by the court on Nov 6, 2024 to conduct reunification therapy. Father’s affidavit and
other records highlight significant issues with Ms. Turner’s involvement. Timeline: Even before the
written order, on Aug 19, 2024, Turner met with the Mother alone (an introductory session), and on
Aug 20 she texted both parties claiming she was “court-appointed” and had seen the Mother 58
– surprising the Father, since no court order existed yet at that time. Father asked if Turner had any
prior relationship with Mother; Turner did not respond 59 . After appointment, Turner scheduled
sessions with A.K. and Mother. In one early joint session (Fall 2024), Turner allegedly told A.K. she did
not believe Mother ever hurt her, and that “the court doesn’t believe you either.” 60 According
to Father, A.K. left that session traumatized, suffered a panic attack, and had to see a pediatrician the
next day, who prescribed anti-anxiety medication for future therapy visits 61 . Turner was also
inflexible with scheduling: she set one therapy session on Nov 12, 2024 that conflicted with A.K.’s
long-scheduled pediatric evaluation; Father begged to reschedule, but Turner refused, causing
A.K. to miss the medical appointment 62 . Turner often was slow to communicate with Father and
seemed to coordinate primarily with Mother 63 . By January 2025, Kelly Turner withdrew from the
case (resigned as therapist). Then, on Feb 12, 2025, the eve of a court hearing, Turner signed an
affidavit (apparently at Mother’s request) accusing the Father of manipulating A.K. and the
reunification process 64 . Turner had never met or spoken with the Father in person during the
therapy process 64 . Father’s counsel moved to strike Turner’s affidavit as one-sided and without
personal knowledge. This conflict with the reunification therapist is a major issue: it suggests Turner
may have had bias or at least that the reunification process was fraught. It also sets the stage for
questioning Turner (the Father has subpoenaed her for trial on Jan 5, 2026) about her methods,
statements to A.K., and lack of impartiality.
• Dr. Eric Tyler (Child’s Counselor/Pediatrician) – Deposition (Sept 10, 2025) – Dr. Tyler is a
pediatrician who treated A.K. and B.M., including for behavioral health. He was deposed in Sept 2025
for this case. His medical records (exhibits to his depo) confirm A.K. has been diagnosed with
Generalized Anxiety Disorder and ADHD 65 . A well-child exam on April 11, 2025 noted A.K.’s
anxiety was “well controlled” with medication, but also listed “CHILD PHYSICAL ABUSE,
CONFIRMED” in her problem list (coded as a “subsequent encounter”) 66 . The history in that report
states: “Father has custody. Maternal physical abuse… Court case is ongoing. Mother has moved…
engaged and pregnant.” 67 . This indicates Dr. Tyler was aware of the abuse allegations and the
4
custody situation. We expect Dr. Tyler’s testimony to support that forcing A.K. into unwanted
contact caused her severe anxiety, and that the therapeutic process might have been mishandled.
(Notably, Dr. Tyler’s scheduled behavioral evaluation of A.K. in Nov 2024 was missed due to the
Turner therapy conflict 62 , something likely covered in his deposition.) His input will be crucial on
whether A.K.’s reluctance is rooted in legitimate trauma versus parental influence.
• Mother’s Perspective: While we have fewer direct documents from the Mother in this folder, we
know from her appeal and filings that she alleges the Father is alienating the children and
disobeying court orders. For instance, the Mother filed an Objection to [Father’s] Motion to Set
Aside Court-Ordered Holiday Visitation in late 2025, which Father’s affidavit explicitly responds to
68 . Mother has claimed Father does not facilitate her visitation (hence the need for the holiday
motion in 2025). In August 2024, Mother’s attorney Matthew Holdren corresponded with Father’s
counsel about the reunification order terms – advocating for Kelly Turner as therapist and opposing
bringing in a new counselor despite CAC’s unavailability 69 70 . Mother’s side insisted that
Turner’s sessions “will be sufficient” until CAC could do joint counseling, and that Mother would
“absolutely participate” in CAC counseling when opened 71 72 . (In practice, however, CAC never did
joint sessions before Turner withdrew, and Mother’s participation in Turner’s sessions became
inconsistent.) The Mother’s Appellate filings (Appeal No. CL-2024-0597) likely argued the trial court
erred in its 2024 custody decision. She obtained extensions to file her brief (due Nov 14, 2024) 73 ,
and the Father (Appellee) filed his brief on Jan 9, 2025. No appellate decision is noted in the record,
suggesting the appeal might still be pending or was rendered moot by the ongoing trial-level
proceedings (the final hearing before Judge Hall will effectively supersede prior interim orders).
• Texts and Emails: The folder contains a PDF of text messages (all parties’ texts through Sept 26,
2025) and some emails. While too voluminous to summarize in full, these communications provide
context: e.g. Emails with Kelly Turner (an email dated Nov 26, 2014 from Turner) show Father
pleading to reschedule A.K.’s session due to the conflict with her doctor appointment 62 (Turner
refused). Texts likely document scheduling conversations and possibly Mother’s cancellations or
A.K.’s statements. One notable mention: on July 31, 2025 (exactly a year after the show-cause
hearing), during a custody exchange for B.M., the Father texted Mother to encourage her to speak
with A.K. in person; Mother stayed in her car, and later A.K. texted Father upset that “her mother
never even got out of the car to speak to me or congratulate me” on something 74 . This incident,
mentioned in Father’s affidavit, underscores the communication breakdown and will be used to
show Mother’s missed opportunities to connect.

Thematic Issues & Tags
Visitation Schedule & Compliance: Initially, Mother had a standard visitation schedule (alternating
weekends, holidays) 2 3 . However, due to A.K.’s resistance, that schedule never fully materialized post-
divorce. The July 2024 plan effectively put normal visits on hold in favor of weekly family meals 28 21 . A
central question is whether Father unjustifiably withheld standard visitation or whether Mother’s own
actions (and A.K.’s trauma) caused the lack of visits. Judge Hall’s Nov 2025 order underscored that Mother’s
regular visitation was never legally suspended 39 , implicitly directing that it should have been happening.
Mother will argue Father should have made A.K. go to visits; Father will point to the police and therapist
advice not to force a panicked child 78 and to Judge Perryman’s acknowledgment that it was A.K.’s issue,
not contempt by Father 14 . Also key: Mother’s inconsistent participation in the alternative “visitation” (the
weekly reunification dinners). Father documented many Mother no-shows in 2025 49 51 , which undercuts
her claim that he impeded contact. This theme will be tied to contempt: Mother’s motion alleged Father
was in contempt for not handing over A.K.; Father was never found in contempt (July 31, 2024 hearing
continued without such finding 14 ), and Father may counter that Mother herself violated the spirit of the
court’s reunification order by missing sessions and falling behind on support 54 .
Reunification Therapy Process: The efficacy of the reunification therapy is a major focus. Kelly Turner’s
role is controversial. From the start, Turner was Mother’s preferred therapist 79 . Father alleges Turner
sided with Mother and traumatized A.K. by dismissing her abuse claims 88 . Turner’s early withdrawal and
accusatory affidavit will be scrutinized. Expect Father to use Turner’s own words against her (e.g. the “court
doesn’t believe you” quote 60 and her refusal to accommodate A.K.’s medical appointment 62 ) to argue
Turner was not a neutral facilitator but rather exacerbated the situation. The defense for Mother might be
that Father sabotaged therapy or that A.K. was influenced by Father to distrust Turner. However, given
Turner refused to meet Father, his influence on Turner was minimal. The court-appointed GAL and Dr. Tyler’s
evidence will weigh in here: if the GAL or doctor find that reunification failed mainly due to the child’s
genuine trauma and Mother’s inconsistent effort, the court may adjust the approach (possibly ordering
a new therapist or even suspending forced reunification until A.K. is willing).
11
Contradictory Orders vs. Oral Rulings: The discrepancy between Judge Perryman’s oral bench ruling and
the written order is well documented. Father calls it a “mistake” that should be corrected 25 26 . This is not
merely technical – it affected an entire year of the family’s life. For example, the bench ruling implied
Mother should earn back normal visitation gradually, whereas the written order could be read as
Mother immediately gets weekly dinners (in addition to her existing visitation rights). The lack of
clarity led to Father believing normal weekend visitation was on hold (since A.K. was not going), while
Mother later argued it was not. This confusion is why Judge Hall found it necessary to state on 11/6/25 that
no suspension existed 39 . The final trial will sort out this contradiction. Father’s position: the intent was a
temporary therapeutic pause on normal visits until A.K. was ready, and the final order in 2024 mistakenly
accelerated things. Mother’s position: the written order is the order – Father should have immediately
facilitated both the therapy and her standard visitation (difficult as that was). Resolving this will likely
involve “resetting” or clarifying the visitation plan in a new order that aligns with the child’s best interests
now, 18 months later. Judge Hall may effectively need to choose which path to endorse moving forward
(gradual/flexible or strict schedule).
Contempt Allegations: On the Father’s side, he may seek to hold Mother in contempt for failure to pay
child support and medical cost shares (she’s ~$1,500 behind, per affidavit 54 ) and possibly for violating
the order to attend reunification sessions (though that order didn’t specify a penalty for missed dinners, her
lack of participation could be seen as bad faith). On Mother’s side, she initially sought contempt against
Father for withholding visitation. Given all the evidence of A.K.’s refusal and Father’s documented efforts
(police reports, etc.), it is unlikely Father will be found in contempt for that period. Judge Perryman
effectively excused him in July 2024 14 . However, Mother might renew contempt claims for later incidents
(e.g. if Father didn’t turn over A.K. for a holiday – though the record shows he even gave extra time on some
holidays 56 ). The GAL’s input will be important on whether either party willfully disobeyed court orders or
simply couldn’t comply due to the child’s behavior. The GAL likely has been monitoring and will report if, for
example, Father discouraged A.K. or Mother spoke negatively to A.K., etc.
In Camera Child Preference: A.K. is now 13. Her preferences carry more weight at this age. It’s expected
that Judge Hall (or through the GAL) will consider A.K.’s wishes in crafting the final order. A.K. has
consistently expressed that she does not feel safe or comfortable with Mother (per her statements to
counselors and the court). Unless evidence shows those fears are unfounded or planted, the court may
adjust visitation accordingly (possibly moving to therapeutic supervised visitation with Mother until A.K.
consents to unsupervised time). The theme of the child’s voice is thus critical. This case already had one in
camera interview; there may be another before the final trial concludes, or the GAL will relay A.K.’s current
feelings. The court must balance this with the policy of reunifying children with parents – a delicate task
given A.K.’s age and prolonged estrangement.
Relocation and Logistics: Mother’s move to Clanton (approx. 2 hours from Father in Alexander City) adds
complexity. Joint dinners on school nights became impractical, which is why Father shifted to weekend
meetings in Prattville (halfway) 99 . The final plan must account for distance. The court might order less
frequent but longer visits, or require the Mother to drive the distance given she moved. Also, Mother’s new
infant means her attention is split; conversely, Father’s obligations with the older kids remain primary. This
relocation issue is tied to “best interests” – stability vs. maintaining a bond at distance.
Bankruptcy and Financial Issues: While the custody court won’t decide bankruptcy law, the situation
sheds light on the parties’ conduct. Father filing bankruptcy in Sept 2024 allowed him to avoid selling the
house and halted Mother’s collection of the $32k. Mother’s creditor claim being treated as unsecured (not

support) was effectively a win for Father 97 98 . Mother’s appeal of that ruling (pending in federal court)
indicates her anger over not getting the money. She might argue in family court that Father’s bankruptcy
was an attempt to deprive her of resources and thus not in good faith (e.g. he chose bankruptcy rather than
obey the order to sell the house 95 ). Father will counter that he proposed a 100% repayment plan (so she’ll
get her money through bankruptcy) 107 and that keeping the house was to maintain the children’s home
stability (he had nowhere else to live with the kids) 108 109 . The bankruptcy transcripts show Father’s
rationale: he took on marital debts (IRS and credit cards) and couldn’t pay everything at once 75 110 . This
context might influence the court’s view of Father’s overall credibility and stress level during 2024–25, but
the family court is unlikely to penalize him for exercising a legal remedy (especially since he did pay $20k
before filing 5 111 ). It could, however, factor into any attorney fee decisions (e.g. Mother could argue
Father’s actions forced her to incur more legal fees).
Therapeutic Intervention Going Forward: Both sides seem to agree that some therapy is needed – but
disagree on how and with whom. The Mother originally opposed involving a new counselor for joint
sessions in 2024 80 , preferring to rely solely on Turner, which proved problematic. Now, with Turner gone,
the path is open. The court may order a new reunification therapist or family therapy program. The
AFCC Guidelines for Court-Involved Therapy (included in the files) may be referenced, emphasizing that a
therapist should maintain impartiality and not take on dual roles. Expect Father to insist on a therapist
independent of Mother’s influence and perhaps one vetted by both parties or the GAL. Mother, on the
other hand, might request that any therapy be local to her (to ease her participation) or even that it isn’t
necessary because she believes Father’s compliance is the main issue. Given A.K.’s anxiety, a trauma-
informed counselor might be appointed to specifically address the mother–daughter relationship in a safe
setting. The final order could require Mother to attend parenting or anger management counseling as well,
if the court finds the root cause was her past behavior (the trial evidence of bruising and yelling could
prompt such requirements).
Alienation vs. Estrangement: The Mother’s narrative likely frames Father’s behavior as parental
alienation – pointing to A.K.’s alignment with Father and refusal to see Mother as something Father
encouraged (she even accused him on Facebook of this 112 ). The Father’s narrative is one of justified
estrangement – that A.K.’s fear of Mother is due to Mother’s own actions (the “mistreatment” that even the
trial court recognized) and that he has tried to heal the relationship (by inviting Mother to events, etc. 55
99 ). The evidence leans toward estrangement: A.K.’s reactions (panic attacks, etc.) are hard to fake for a
child, and Father did facilitate many contacts. However, the Mother will seize on any evidence that Father
could have done more or that he harbors bitterness (for example, Father’s bankruptcy and refusal to sell
the house as ordered could be cast as him prioritizing his interests over cooperation). The GAL’s report will
be pivotal here – an unbiased view of whether the Father has been encouraging or discouraging the
children’s relationship with Mother. If the GAL opines that Father has done what he can and Mother needs
to take accountability for repairing her bond with A.K., that will support maintaining Father’s custody and
possibly continuing a cautious approach to Mother’s visitation. Conversely, if the GAL suspects Father of
subtle alienation, the court might impose remedies (like makeup visitation, counseling for Father, or even a
change in custody if extreme – though that seems unlikely given the history).
In Camera & Child’s Testimony: A.K. may not testify in open court (to protect her), but her voice will be
heard either via GAL or another in camera interview with Judge Hall. B.M., the younger child (now about 8),
has been having regular visitation with Mother without noted issue – Father’s affidavit indicates he “ensured
B.M. maintained his normal visitation” even when A.K. would not go 99 . This split situation (one child
visiting, one refusing) is telling: it undercuts a pure alienation claim (since B.M. wasn’t kept away from

supervise A.K.’s visitation until A.K. chooses to resume normal visits, while allowing B.M. unsupervised
visits as before.
